awd_titl_txt: Probes, Labels, Traps, and Reporters: Exploring the Modern Spin Chemistry Landscape
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanisms-B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Malcolm D. E. Forbes of the Department of Chemistry at Bowling Green State University is investigating the structure, changes (dynamics), and reactivity of free radicals. Free radicals are short-lived, very reactive species resulting from the fragmentation of stable molecules which have been exposed to heat or light. Free radicals are characterized by having unpaired electrons, in contrast to most stable molecules in their lowest energy state, which have all of their electrons paired. Using a specialized spectroscopic technique called time-resolved electron paramagnetic resonance, free radicals can be observed on short time scales in organized structures such as vesicles (biological cell mimics), micelles (oil droplets in water), bubbles, polymer matrices, and other supramolecular structures such as organic nanocrystals. The results provide a deeper understanding of entangled spin states, which have potential use in quantum computing, quantum sensing, and quantum information systems. The scientific impact of the work reaches the fields of medicine, quantum computing (control of highly entangled electron spin systems), coatings (thin film curing and drying), and photocatalysis and drug delivery. The Forbes' laboratory is active in public outreach to libraries and museums. They participate in a summer research program for high school students in Northwest Ohio.

Spin wave function evolution and molecular motion are intimately connected in spectroscopic methods, especially time-resolved electron paramagnetic resonance (TREPR).  Their dynamics can be analyzed through the use of theoretical models such as the nano-reactor model for spin-correlated radical pairs. A major thrust of the project is to place the radical-triplet pair mechanism (RTPM) of chemically induced electron spin polarization on a stronger theoretical footing, and in doing so make it more useful for understanding the nature of molecular motion in confined spaces on the nanoscale. The advantages in using RTPM spin polarization for experimental studies of molecular dynamics in both homogeneous and heterogeneous systems include the magnitude of the electron spin polarization observed in the nitroxide is directly dependent on the number of encounters it experiences with the photoexcited triplet state, providing quantitative translational diffusion information.  The team also investigates the line shape of the nitroxide spin reporter (intensities, line widths, hyperfine couplings) gives information about polarity and viscosity, in particular rotational mobility.  The excited triplet state is silent in the TREPR spectrum because of fast electron spin relaxation, induced by modulation of the dipolar interaction and this advantages is exploited by the team.  Finally, neither the triplet precursor or the nitroxide are consumed during the experiment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In our laboratory we use light to break chemical bonds. The resulting fragments are called "free radicals" which are unstable intermediate structures. We try to understand these fragments in detail because this helps us to predict their eventual disposition in the environment. For example, some of these intermediates arise from the breakdown of plastics in sunlight.  Others may come from agricultural products like herbicides and pesticides, also exposed to the sun for long periods of time.  Because of the instability of free radicals, they are difficult to detect, so we have devised and constructed very special instrumentation to observe them in real time as they decay to their eventual stable photoproducts. In this regard, free radicals either recombine to make the original molecule, or (more commonly) undergo additional reactions to make new molecules. Sometimes they can react in a chain fashion to create polymers.  A unique feature of free radicals is that they have unpaired electrons, which is the source of their high reactivity.

The process by which the radicals are produced depends on the original structure and the type of light (visible, ultra-violet) used to excite it. The nature of the products formed afterwards depends on several factors: 1) the structure of the free radicals formed via fragmentation, 2) their ability to approach each other (we can alter this by placing them in "restricted" environments, and 3) the orientation of the "spin" angular momentum vectors of the unpaired electrons. You can imagine "spin" like the Earth rotating about its axis over a 24 hour day. The Earth spins slowly and only in one direction. Unpaired electrons spin very quickly and can spin in either direction, called “spin up” and “spin down.”

It turns out that all three factors listed above are connected and each can affect the outcome of radical reactions in different ways. If the radicals are large, they may have difficulty making contact. If they are placed in a very viscous environment like an oil, or a polymer matrix or an emulsion (like a cosmetics cream), they may also fail to approach each other to react. Finally, if their electron spin angular momentum vectors (spin up vs. spin down) are not properly aligned, they may not react at all. This is a very important point: two unpaired electrons that are both spin up or both spin down cannot make a new chemical bond. They must have opposite spin orientations to react and make new stable molecules.

We study the outcome of light-induced free radical reactions with an eye towards total understanding of all three factors listed above. We can create radicals in free solution, in small nanocrystals, in soap bubbles and droplets, and in long polymer chains. The interplay between the diffusion between the radicals and their spin alignment can lead to widely different magnetic properties, which we study with a technique called electron paramagnetic resonance. This method simultaneously gives us information about the dynamics (movement between radicals), the radical structures (how are all the bonds in the free radicals are connected together), and their reactivity (are the spins aligned to make bonds or not?).

By understanding all three aspects of these reactions (structure, dynamics, reactivity), we may be able to better understand some industrial processes such as the formation and degradation of plastics, the flow of paints and coatings, and the ability of catalysts to efficiently convert light into energy. In addition, we can explore the role of electron spin is a new field of science called “Quantum Information Science”, which has the potential to drastically increase computer speeds and lead to essentially unhackable encrypted communication signals.
